Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2008 12:45PM Hope_M wrote: Oh, Jen, I'm so sorry for your news.  But do not leap to the conclusion that your choices are limited to how you will die!  Goodness, I've been reading these boards for over 4 years now, and there are many Stage 4 ladies who have successfully eliminated liver mets and have controlled bone mets for literally years.  I know that you've been told that this is fatal (and it may well be for you) BUT IF your cancer happens to be responsive to the chemos that are available, then you have an excellent opportunity to control them and live more years with good quality of life.  I think that you need to do a bit more research on your options and make sure that you have an oncologist with whom you feel comfortable and who can offer you hope.   Stage 4 ladies???  Please post for Jen! Hugs, Hope M.

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2009 03:54PM Hope_M wrote: Hi, Joanne- The LE means lymphedema.  I don't know the setting on the ultrasound machine, but we used it on the saline implant (no port to worry about). A good massage therapist has helped me release pec minor and adhesions in serratus anterior which were compromising lymphatic flow (mine tries to drain over the shoulder in the back now) and movement of the arm.  Also, I now go to an OT who has training in the Chickley method of lymphatic drainage (as well as visceral manipulation and cranial-sacral therapy).  She has helped release some of the radiation fibrosis and much scar tissue.  Finding  a therapist who is hands-on and trained in lots of ways can be a godsend in dealing with the aftermath of radiation and surgery.  You have to find someone who has "knowledge" in their hands.  You'll know them when they work on you.  Good luck, everyone! Hope M.
Posts.Title: lets talk implant capsulating?? joanne2 joanne2

Posts.Content: May 24, 2008 07:51PM Hope_M wrote: Argh!  I'm sorry to hear this. I think that the purple color MAY be due to the thin layer of skin over it.  When my implant was threatening to pop out through the skin, my mastectomy scar turned dark as well.  The surgeon said that was because we were seeing the implant through the skin, which was only a few cells thick at that point. I asked my surgeon about options for another port when we had this one removed.  She said that it was no problem to put one in on the other side.  I hope that this will be an option for you as well.  Around here, most surgeons can do this. Hope that it all works out! Hope M.
Posts.Title: port problem remgirl remgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 06:16PM Hope_M wrote: Dear Joanne, Often encapsulation or contracture happens right away.  When it does, it is pretty relentless. If you are doing well so far, then that is great.  You will need to massage in order to prevent scar tissue formation.  Ultrasound has been proven to be of limited help as well.  I had good luck using therapists (both massage and occupational) who were highly skilled in order to release scar adhesions. Best of luck, Hope M.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 03:59PM Hope_M wrote: After 6 years of reading on these boards, it is very true that everyone's reactions to the same chemo regimens vary.  Some women who had my chemo were able to continue working; I could not have imagined working with the reactions that I had.  My first chemo almost killed me; my fifth had almost no symptoms.  It is important to accept this variability in reactions and not to assume that our own experience will mirror someone else's. My sister once calculated that I was a certain percentage finished with my chemo.  It perked me up to realize how far I'd come successfully.   Hugs to everyone still in treatment! Hope M. TX: mastectomy, 6 TAC chemo, 25 rads, 1 year weekly Herceptin

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 06:39PM Hope_M wrote: Hey, Pepper B! Nice to see you. It was the radiologist (the doctor) not the tech, I think, who spoke to Lisajo. Lisajo, I don't believe that you should wait the 6 months. DCIS can go invasive. They do not know yet which cases will and which cases are safe, which is why they have to "overtreat" it. Perhaps the doctor did not mean DCIS, but "benign calcifications"? I would recommend a second opinion at a BREAST center with a specialist. Re: the pain: Although studies show that breast cancer "doesn't hurt", the anecdotal truth is that many of us on this site felt pain with our lumps. What you are describing sounds more like infection or perhaps a blocked lymph node and channels. That can happen for LOTS of reasons (like slight dehydration; too much food that irritates your system slightly, like sugar or things you are allergic to; or even a cold) other than cancer. Hope you get a second opinion. Listen to your gut and press on until YOU feel satisfied with the answers. Good luck! Hope M.

Posts.Content: Hope_M wrote: I had a double biopsy over a week ago.  It was MRI guided stereotactic and they had to tunnel all the way over to the sternum side of the breast from the armpit side in two areas.  I've got a huge internal hematoma which is pretty hard and is showing no signs of softening.  It takes up about a quarter of the interior of my breast, which is a size B going into a C (so this is a big thing). At what time point do I begin to think that this needs to be looked at again?  My gynocologist felt it about five days after the biopsy and said that it needs to begin to soften in 2 - 3 days, which have now passed. The only change since then has been some settling of the blood to make new bruising (but it is yellow, not purple, so that is good.)  The lump seems just as large and hard. Please post if you have any advice for me!  I appreciate it-- Hope M. Oh, and P.S. the results of the biopsies were benign, which is wonderful!  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2009 11:29PM Hope_M wrote: Dear Notinvincible, I didn't have time to read through all of your responses, but be reassured that the knee pain is not likely to be mets.  Is it on both sides? If so, that is another indicator against mets and for arthritis or a benign joint issue. Mets typically set up in the long bones or in other areas with larger deposits of bone marrow, not in joints.  I know that you are scared, but I hope that my numbers will reassure you:  an 8 by 9 by 2 cm tumor with four positive nodes (one was over 2 cms and "exploded" with cancer), ER/PR negative and Her2+.  I am still NED after 6.5 years!!!   You have a long tunnel of harsh treatments ahead of you, but you have much to hope for! Hope M.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 08:31PM Hope_M wrote: Dear Rusty, Your story touches me so much.  Traci says it so well:  We are hear to listen, to lean on and to love. I hope that you will forgive me for speaking frankly.  I hear the fear in your posts.  You sound so strong in yourself, that I suspect that you are not as afraid of your own suffering as you are of leaving your boys.  (I also have three boys, now aged 18, 16 and 10.)  There is nothing that any of us can say that can ease that heartache. I think that all of the women on these boards who have children, whether young or grown, have had the thoughts and fears that you are faced with now in a very real way.  As a Stage3er myself, with positive nodes, I have considered my death and how it would affect my boys.  Now that they are a bit older, I honestly think that losing their dad would be worse for them than losing me.  Boys need their dad in their teen years.  My husband is a real winner, a nurturer who is devoted to his family. He has worked hard to stay in good communication with all of our boys and he has a great relationship with all of them. Your husband sounds similar.  If life forces him to, your husband will take wonderful care of the boys.  This is piss-poor consolation, I know. Rusty, don't waste another precious minute second-guessing your treatment decisions.  I wish that I could give you a hug in person. Hope M.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 05:08PM Hope_M wrote: Dear Fiona, The largest concern is the number of positive nodes.  At this point, you have to assume that there are cancer cells circulating in your blood and lymph.  The great news is that you were Her2 positive and should be recommended to take Herceptin, an immunotherapy with fairly light side effects (usually!!!  As you will learn, "your mileage may vary" with responses to chemo and other treatments.)  When Herceptin works, it is a real miracle, with even stage 4 ladies having good response and control of disease for years.  Genentech, the maker of Herceptin, has a site with more information about it. Please keep posting and let us know what your proposed treatment is so that we can help more. Good luck!  I can tell that you are a survivor having gone through this year so far. Hope M.
Posts.Title: Everything is happening so fast fiona1144 lpizza726

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 09:52AM Hope_M wrote: Regarding the mind body connection:  I'll never forget hearing a doctor give a presentation at a conference where he said that the mind body connection is so well-established and accepted even by conventional medical researchers that EVERY clinical trial of any type has to account for it.   It is called the "placebo effect" and it accounts for at least 10% of the measurable response of patients to treatments (which is why they have blind and double-blind trials and control groups who receive only placebos. Interesting! Hope M.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2008 01:31PM Hope_M wrote: Dear dlt10960, You are NOT guaranteed to have your cancer come back.  I know that you are scared, but remember that the women who continue to seek support on this and other BC sites after initial dx and treatment are often the women who do have a recurrance or metastasis. It is a self-selected group.  Just listen to your oncologist and ask what the odds of recurrance or metastasis are for your individual case. I was diagnosed at stage 3 as well.  I also had four positive nodes and no family history.  I am now approaching the five year mark (next May) and have remained cancer-free so far.   Why not assume that you, too, will be like me? I know that it is scary.  But you will slowly become more at ease with it all.  You have a lot to learn, and very quickly.  It all seems overwhelming at first.  Hang in there and take a deep breath when you need one. Good luck with it all and keep asking questions-- Hope M.

He will not leave you in this time. Seek Him with all your heart and He will be found by you, regardless of the cancer outcome. Best wishes, Hope M.

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 06:58AM Hope_M wrote: Heidi, I second those who encourage you to write notes or letters to be given to your children on special occasions (their graduation, marriage, birth of child, etc.)  As a stage 3C, I once surveyed my parenting community on line and those who had lost parents early really treasured these letters. We have a local charity called "Let There Be Mom" who works with parents to provide a profession photo shoot with the family and with their children along with scrapbooks and videos.  Perhaps there is such a charity near you, but if not, you could still do a professional photo shoot with the family before you lose your hair, if possible.  The photos are a real gift. All of that having been said, do not give up hope.  You are young and strong and it is amazing what the body can do to heal.  Please let us know how it goes. Hope M.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 10:56PM Hope_M wrote: Dear Tiffany, I hear your frustration.  When the treatments are over, we are still left with a changed life--every unusual and persistent pain will result in a scan of some type, for example, for many years to come.  So in a way you are almost at the end of a long dark tunnel, but you also need your friends and loved ones not to sweep your fears (and very real permanent changes under the rug).  Maybe you could try telling them that? Maybe say something like, "I appreciate your encouragement, and I will be glad to move on from the chemo, but I need you to understand that in many ways my life will never be the same.  Do you think that you can support me as I adapt emotionally to this?" Now that I am 6.5 years out and have been reading these boards since 2003, I can say that for some of us, the mindset does indeed move on. We "get our lives back", so to speak.  I carry permanent physical discomforts and compromises every day (lymphedema, radiation fibrosis of the pectoral muscle, etc.) that I have to fight with a routine of treatments by occupational and massage therapists and chiropractic care.  But I feel at peace with my new normal, and I am often joyful on a daily basis. Try to embrace the coming end of the treatment.  Treatment sucks WAY more than anything else I've been through so far, and that includes multiple reconstructive surgeries and the complications I listed above.  WOO HOO for hair and feeling better!!! Good luck with radiation-- Hope M.
Posts.Title: Tired of hearing it's almost over! TiffanyF4 Diana63

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 12:00AM Hope_M wrote: Deb, you lived well.  Not perfectly, but with humor and energy and a huge smile.  Yes, you transcended your breast cancer.  Our loss is heaven's gain.  Maybe God just needed you close by to crack Him up on the tough days . . . like we did. BC Sisters, I know that this is painful.  If you stay on these boards for five years or more, you will gain and lose several priceless sisters like Deb.  Not many, but more than a handful, and all of them very bitter losses to accept.  Cry if you need to, but don't shy away from the love that we share here. When we lose someone as unique as Deb, loving expressions and memories surge onto the discussion boards, out into cyber space, and into the fabric of this virtual community that unites so many of us from vastly different worlds. In memory of Deb, turn to your sisters here and post in support.  Go to the newly diagnosed thread and encourage someone; look for women whose posts haven't been answered yet and be a friend. In memory of Deb, share the humor in your life.  Don't wallow in the bad stuff. In memory of Deb and the other mothers of young children who have died, reach out to a young mother in your "real" world who needs a hand.  Or befriend a child whose mom or dad is out of the picture for whatever reason. In memory of Deb, always smile your biggest smile for the camera and love your family in the daily-ness that is life. Deb, darn it.  You shouldn't have been so unique, so irreplaceable.  Love, Hope M.

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2008 08:31PM - edited Jul 19, 2008 08:33PM by Hope_M Dear LuAnn, I struggle with blood pressure after surgeries.  It just takes so long for me to bounce back, systemically speaking.  Just give it some more time, hydrate, and try to change position slowly.   I don't know what meds you are on, but if any of them can depress BP as a side effect (like a heart med such as Toprol), then you may want to go off of them for a while. Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 09:53PM Hope_M wrote: My oncologist specifically told me that unless a lymph node was already enlarged due to cancer, it would not show up as suspicious on a CT.  That is the advantage of the PET, which can tell the difference in a normally-sized lymph node with cancer vs. one that doesn't have cancer.  Hope M.
Posts.Title: CT scan jan-m jan-m

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 09:12PM Hope_M wrote: Dear Randieclipper, Your head must be spinning with the news from the biopsy and here we are with all of our opinions about your surgeon!  I'm sorry for your news and hope that you can take a deep breath.  YOU HAVE TIME to think about this and to research it further.  I truly second what Beesie said on every point, and Otter also brings up the excellent point about the Sentinal Node Biopsy. In my experience, you should now be offered a breast MRI of both breasts, expecially if the extent of the tumor is not suggested by the ultrasound and mammogram.  Using the scans, you would decide on the extent of surgery that you want to undergo.  You may need to consult with an oncologist to find out if chemotherapy BEFORE surgery (neoadjuvant treatment) is desirable. Good luck with it all, and keep coming back to us.  I for one would be happy to take a phone call from you, if you just want to ask someone some answers in person.  Just send me a private message via this site, if you want my number.   Hugs, Hope M.
Posts.Title: Saw the surgeon today and even more confused ranD Beesie

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 11:13PM Hope_M wrote: An "oncogene" is a subset of the full DNA strand of the cancer cell.  The Oncotype dx testing should help indicate whether or not your particular cancer would be responsive to chemotherapy or not.  As recently as 5 - 6 years ago, they knew that chemo would help only a percentage of cancer patients, but they didn't know who would fall into that percentage.  So they gave chemo to everyone who met certain criteria (size of tumor, positivity of lymph nodes, etc.), knowing that for many of them it was not really necessary.  The oncotype dx testing has helped to refine the choice of who really will benefit from chemo. I hope that you have a good result on that test! Hope M.
Posts.Title: Oncatype dx testing? Anxiousmama mich1224

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2010 02:01AM Hope_M wrote: Hi, Sharon- This is most likely scar tissue formation under your arm where the surgery took place.  Another possibility is a type of cording associated with lymphatic channels damaged by the lymph node removal.  I am 7 years out and still have occasional therapy to stretch and release scar tissue and adhesions under my arm.  A good physical therapist or occupational therapist will probably be able to help you.  Also, lymphedema can be present without noticeable swelling.  My affected arm runs 2 - 3 cms larger at the top than the normal arm, and without my being able to notice that without actually measuring. Good luck! Hope M.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 06:46PM Hope_M wrote: Oh, yes, the "Uncle Fester" days . . . I always said that as a woman you can be fat OR bald, but not both at the same time!  It does suck, big time and I feel for all of you who are fresh out of treatment! My cures were oncology rehab and a personal trainer, which fixed the achy joints and bones, and just plain time.  My curly post-chemo hair is much closer to pre-chemo now, but it took five years or so to get there. Hang in there! Hope M. dx Stage III May '03
Posts.Title: Stage III Recently Diagnosed What are Your Issues? Shanagirl Shanagirl

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 09:04PM Hope_M wrote: One other consideration is whether the mastectomy would save you the radiation. Even though it is often not a difficult part of treatment to go through, it can have long-term effects (including fibrosis of the pectoral muscle which is painful and motion limiting) which might be a consideration for you. Hope M.
